name: casting, bronze | casting, bronze | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/7113/documentation

All data are calculated based on assumptions and theoretical models. Their overall quality is poor.;[This dataset was already contained in the ecoinvent database version 2. It was not individually updated during the transfer to ecoinvent version 3. Life Cycle Impact Assessment results may still have changed, as they are affected by changes in the supply chain, i.e. in other datasets. This dataset was generated following the ecoinvent quality guidelines for version 2. It may have been subject to central changes described in the ecoinvent version 3 change report (http://www.ecoinvent.org/database/ecoinvent-version-3/reports-of-changes/), and the results of the central updates were reviewed extensively. The changes added e.g. consistent water flows and other information throughout the database. The documentation of this dataset can be found in the ecoinvent reports of version 2, which are still available via the ecoinvent website. The change report linked above covers all central changes that were made during the conversion process.]

The activity starts with the input of the heat and electricity that will melt the bronze (metal not included).

melting of copper and tin and casting of bronze parts. Metal input is not included.
category: C:Manufacturing/24:Manufacture of basic metals/243:Casting of metals/2432:Casting of non-ferrous metals

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Data relate to the European average.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Assumed energy mix for melting. Abatement of air emissions assumed
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: none This dataset has been copied from an original dataset covering the geography CH. The uncertainty has been adjusted accordingly.

exchanges.description:
Proxy: "filter dust from electrolysis, 0% water" is used as a proxy for dust from filters (to recycling).

Estimation from dataset author: Dust filters are commonly used to abate metal emissions.
